description: Originally Scots, possibly from Middle Low German schö̂ne (“fine flour bread”), or from Greek σκόνη (skóni, “dust”) or Middle Dutch schoonbroot (“fine bread; a kind of flat angular loaf”), from schoon (“fine”) + broot (“bread”); alternatively, Scottish Gaelic sgonn (“lump, mouthful”).

entries.meaning: A small, rich, pastry or quick bread, sometimes baked on a griddle.
(Utah, Idaho) Frybread served with honey butter spread on it.
examples: Dinner rolls and deep-fried crusty scones that border on loaf-size or juicy fruit pies tagged with county-fair blue ribbons rise from backroad eating sites.
…the white ball left a 5cm gash on his scone despite a floppy white hat absorbing some of the impact.

verbs.description: scone (third-person singular simple present scones, present participle sconing, simple past and past participle sconed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang, Australia, New Zealand) To hit on the head.
